breaking_news.title: OpenClaw AI Agent Secrets Stolen by Infostealer Malware
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Cybersecurity researchers discovered that infostealer malware has successfully exfiltrated OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot/Moltbot) configuration files, including API keys, authentication tokens, and internal secrets. This marks the first known instance of infostealers targeting AI agent development environments rather than traditional browser credentials.

Paragraph 2: The theft of OpenClaw’s configuration data compromises the integrity of AI agent deployments, enabling attackers to impersonate legitimate agents, intercept communications, or deploy malicious behaviors. This represents a critical shift in infostealer capabilities toward stealing digital identities and operational tooling used in next-generation AI infrastructure.

breaking_news.title: ClickFix Malware Abuses nslookup for DNS-Based Malware Delivery
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The ClickFix threat group has evolved its social engineering tactics to abuse the built-in Windows nslookup utility to smuggle and execute second-stage payloads via DNS queries. Instead of relying solely on PowerShell or mshta, attackers trick victims into running malicious nslookup commands that parse DNS responses to retrieve RAT payloads like ModeloRAT.

Paragraph 2: This technique bypasses traditional endpoint security controls that block PowerShell and script execution, significantly expanding ClickFix’s evasion capabilities. Microsoft and Malwarebytes have confirmed active exploitation, affecting enterprise and consumer endpoints globally.

breaking_news.title: Google Patches First Actively Exploited Chrome Zero-Day of 2026
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Google released emergency updates for Chrome to patch CVE-2026-2441, a high-severity (CVSS 8.8) use-after-free vulnerability in the CSS component actively exploited in the wild. Security researcher Shaheen Fazim responsibly disclosed the flaw on February 11, 2026, and exploitation allowed remote code execution within the browser sandbox.

Paragraph 2: As the first Chrome zero-day exploited in 2026, this vulnerability poses immediate risk to all Chrome users—especially high-value targets like executives, journalists, and activists—given Chrome’s dominance in enterprise and consumer environments.

breaking_news.title: Lazarus APT Targets Developers via Malicious npm and PyPI Packages
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Researchers identified malicious npm and PyPI packages linked to North Korea’s Lazarus Group as part of a long-running fake recruitment campaign named “graphalgo.” The campaign, active since May 2025, uses deceptive job offers to trick developers into installing infected packages containing backdoors and credential stealers.

Paragraph 2: This supply chain attack targets the software development lifecycle, enabling lateral movement and persistent access to corporate networks. Given Lazarus’s history of high-impact financial and infrastructure attacks, this campaign significantly raises the risk for tech companies and financial institutions using open-source tooling.

breaking_news.title: BeyondTrust Flaw CVE-2026-1731 Added to CISA KEV Catalog
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: CISA added CVE-2026-1731—a critical pre-authentication remote code execution flaw (CVSS 9.9) in BeyondTrust Remote Support and older Privileged Remote Access products—to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. The vulnerability, disclosed February 6, 2026, allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary OS commands.

Paragraph 2: With CISA mandating federal agencies to patch within three days, this flaw poses severe risk to any organization using BeyondTrust solutions for privileged access. Its inclusion in KEV signals active exploitation and imminent threat to critical infrastructure and enterprise environments.

breaking_news.title: ZeroDayRAT Mobile Spyware Advertised on Telegram for Real-Time Surveillance
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A new mobile spyware platform, ZeroDayRAT, is being actively marketed on Telegram for Android and iOS devices, offering real-time surveillance, keystroke logging, location tracking, and microphone access. The operator provides dedicated sales, support, and update channels, indicating a commercial spyware-as-a-service model.

Paragraph 2: This tool poses a severe threat to high-value targets including executives, journalists, activists, and government officials. Its availability on open forums increases the risk of widespread abuse by both state and non-state actors, especially given its evasion capabilities and cross-platform support.

breaking_news.title: ShinyHunters Leaks Trigger Data Breaches at Canada Goose, Figure, and Dior
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: ShinyHunters has leaked over 600,000 Canada Goose customer records, while also claiming responsibility for breaches at fintech firm Figure (allegedly exposing all applicant PII) and luxury brands including Dior, Louis Vuitton, and Tiffany & Co.—which were fined $25M in South Korea for Salesforce-targeted compromises linked to Scattered LAPSUS$ Hunters.

Paragraph 2: These incidents highlight the growing threat of data extortion groups reselling or publishing stolen datasets even when the original breach vector is indirect (e.g., third-party platforms like Salesforce). Organizations face regulatory penalties, reputational damage, and legal liability despite disputing the breach origin.

breaking_news.title: Google Ads and Claude AI Abused to Spread MacSync Malware via ClickFix
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Moonlock Lab researchers uncovered a ClickFix campaign leveraging hijacked Google Ads and fake Claude AI guides to trick macOS users into installing the MacSync infostealer. The attack uses social engineering to诱导 victims to run malicious JavaScript in their browsers, enabling credential theft and session hijacking.

Paragraph 2: By exploiting trusted platforms (Google Ads, AI assistants), attackers achieve high click-through and infection rates. This demonstrates the increasing convergence of AI misuse, ad fraud, and malware delivery—posing elevated risk to Mac users in enterprise and personal environments.
